PROPOSITION.TITRE: Melodic sobriety characterizes most of the musical repertoires.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: This sobriety is shown in the use of elementary isochronous and bichronous rhythmic values and the looped repetition of the phrases –most often organized in three- or four-beat motifs, with the horizontality of the melodic lines unrolling within a narrow ambitus (two or three tones).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The simplicity of a simbong melodic segment, Pangngala' region.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The soloists are distinguished by their superior ability and virtuosity.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The soloists’virtuosity is noticeable in the repertoires of the West in their leading the badong song and in the marakka lamentation; and in the repertoires of the East, in the great simbong chorus and in the repertoires for flutes in the pakorong ritual. Their skills are much greater than those of the musicians who accompany them.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Ornate melodic line of Pa' Indo’Tobong, a piece in the marakka repertoire, recorded at Buntao’in 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The marakka singers are highly skilled in the vocal arts. In the melodies they sing, the note values stretch out languorously, then are broken off suddenly by a twirling ornamentation that smothers the pulse.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Spectrogram. Beginning of a marakka piece, a flute and two women’s voices. The image shows first the flute’s ornamented inflections and then, the descending inflection of the voice, emphasised by the passage from mode 2 to mode 1 on reaching F.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the great choruses of the East, a soloist leads the group with his voice. This voice intones the introductions, indicates vowel changes, the passages to the ‘words’, and announces the end. The soloist’s voice undulates in disconcerting sinuosities.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Example of soloist’s voice in the simbong.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The art of the flute is displayed on two occasions: it is played solo to accompany the voice of the marakka at the funerals, and in quartet for the ritual for expelling smallpox. For the latter the soloists display a remarkable dexterity –as much in the slow passages as in the fast.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Suling deata flute piece, recorded at the pakorong ritual, 1993. The soloist’s virtuosity is conspicuous in his command of the rapid tempo.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The apocope is a recurrent stylistic feature.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The apocope is defined by the loss of a phoneme –or one or more syllables –at the end of a word. In many repertoires, the phrase ends are abruptly truncated: the last syllable of the line disappears in singing as though stifled. The musical accent is often placed on the antepenultimate syllable (paroxytone).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Example of apocope in the retteng repertoire.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The end of all the badong, very incisive, always finishes with a truncated term, often indo’ (‘mother’) or ambe' (‘father’) –addresses choked with an abrupt halt.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Final phrase of a badong, Rantetayo, lines 10-13.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the dondi’sitting chorus, apocope is frequent. The last three syllables are sung in acceleration and the last note –always cut off –consequently elides the final syllable.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Example of apocope in first line: the word rante is cut in two. Dondi’ of Pangngala’.
The end of the line is almost cut off, dondi’ from Pangngala’, 1991.
Example of abrupt ending in a dondi’ melodic pattern, Tikala region.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the retteng the last syllable of each octosyllable is truncated and moved into the following musical period.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Example of apocope in the retteng.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In the simbong, the last word, often the most important (sumanga' ‘vital energy’, lemo ‘lemon’, a metaphor for gold, bulayan ‘gold’) is often truncated in the musical phrase.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: From end of simbong (Poka 4).

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The semitone is used expressively.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: A true expressive technique, the rise by a semitone, of two kinds, recurs in numerous repertoires. It is a source of tension contrasting with the monotonous horizontality of the reciting tone. In both cases, using the semitone structures the melodic composition and intensifies expression.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The semitone in the dondi’. Pangngala’, line 82.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: An identical melody is played a semitone above.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: G. Rouget (‘Un chromatisme africain, L'homme I, 1961, 3: 32-46) then talks of ‘melodic chromaticism’; in this case, the recurrence of the semitone gives the melody its pattern. Ascending before descending, often used at the beginning of the line, each time, this semitone’s presence colors the reciting tone by renewing the dynamic.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: The melodic semitone in the dondi’.
The semitone in the great chorus of the East. Between each phrase, the soloist climbs by a semitone. The note is said to be ‘sucked’(disirok). Singer Indo’Tandirerung, Ulusalu, 1993.
The descending semitone in the marakka.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: A melodic semitone operates at the level of the musical phrase.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The melodic formulas, sometimes built on one tone, most often extend over a three-tone scale.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Each degree of the ‘matrix-scale’assumes a similar melodic function in all the repertoires: the lowest note, number 3, is used as the intonation pitch; the intermediary pitch, the central tone, number 5, is most often used as the termination tone or reciting tone –in the badong; the tone above, number 6, used as the reciting tone –in the dondi’; and lastly, the added tone are only provisional attractions allowing expressive variations.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Figure A: minimal scale on one tone; Figure B: three-tone scale.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Reading code.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The three-tone matrix scale may be enhanced by adding a tone or rising semitone.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The enhanced three-tone scale can be considered a tetraphonic scale with the extra tone (a semi tone or a tone) regularly used by the soloists who often ornament in fourths.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: The basic scale and its developments (Figures C and D).

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The matrix scale would appear to arise from the harmonic series.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: To designate the matrix scale –G Bb C –Kurt Reinhard uses the term nucleus and suggests that pentatonism arose from that (Reinhard 1958). The succession of intervals (approximating minor third, second, and second could correspond to the succession of harmonics 6, 7, 8, 9 in the harmonic series (taking C as h1).
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Place of the Toraja matrix scale in bold in the harmonic series.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The marakka repertoire has a special scale of its own.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Only the scale of the marakka repertoire –like an amputated slendro scale –has an ambitus wider than a fifth by a semitone. The flute covers the whole of it whilst the voices’ambitus is more restricted.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Marakka scale.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The drone is characteristic of the repertoires of the rituals of the East.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In the music of the rituals of the East, the pieces have a similar two-part composition opposing a homophonic drone to a soloist embroidering a second above and below.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Table of the repertoires: in gray, repertoires using drone

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The drone can be alternately continuous or discontinuous, both in vocal and instrumental music. The continuous drone of the flutes and fiddles of healing recalls that of the simbong. Whereas in the latter the drone becomes syllabic during the recitation of the lyrics, in the instrumental repertoires it is discontinuous (rhythmic) in the rapid tempo melodies.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Continuous drone in a piece for flute (buku suling penduan), pakorong ritual, 1993.
From the beginning of a simbong chorus, before pronouncing the words.
Discontinuous drone in a quartet of flutes (suling deata), pakorong ritual, 1993. Title: *Bunyi kecapi orang dulu.
Discontinuous drone in a simbong song, Poka, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The harmonic second is the interval favored.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The second is clearly the harmonic interval most sought for. It is the most frequent both in the repertoires of the rituals of the East and those of the rituals of the West.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: VIDEO: Nani (or dondo, dandan) chorus in seconds, Ulusalu, August 1993.
Presence of seconds in simbong chorus.
Presence of seconds in the dondi’ chorus.
Presence of seconds in the badong,Tapparan.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Size of the harmonic second varies depending on the group.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The interval of a second that determines the degree of brilliance differs from group to group: the limits of the second vary from 140 to 250 cents, i.e. a difference of nearly a semitone depending on the chorus. The sonorous choruses, ‘clear’and ‘sharp’, use a very large second (between 220 and 250 cents –nearly a minor third) while the choruses who ‘sound less’use a smaller second (140 cents).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: A wide second: in the experienced choruses –Lo'ko’Lemo, Awan SangPolo –the harmonic interval favored generally stabilizes on ratios of about 7/6, 8/7 (above 220cents) or of 9/8 (between 200 and 220 cents). Here, the chorus of Lo'ko’Lemo, Poka 2, 1993.

A narrower second: in the less experienced choruses, the blending ratios are smaller –9/8, 10/9, 11/10, 12/11, 13/12, 14/13 –as the blending is created with more distant harmonics, the harmonics 9, 10, 11 instead of 6, 7, 8. Here, simbong of Baruppu', lines 4-5, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Widening of the harmonic interval within a single piece.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In all the simbong pieces, one aspect invariably stands out: the gap between the two voices widens as the piece progresses until stabilizing. At the beginning, the gap is less than a tone. It will nearly always be larger at the end –except for the choruses of Se'seng, who sometimes conclude on a ratio of 10/9, i.e., a very small second. Sometimes the differences between the beginning and the end within the same piece are on the order of a semitone.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Beginning of the simbong song (SPO 4), recorded at Poka. The interval changes from 165 cents (ratio 11/10) at the beginning to 252 cents (ratio 7/6) at the end. Although the drone drops, the soloist stays on a level. In other cases, the drone note above all tends to go down while the soloist tends to adjust by climbing. Most of the time the soloist tries to keep the interval stable.
Beginning of a simbong (SA 21-25), Awan.
Beginning of a simbong, Se'seng, Track 13.
Ending of a simbong (SPO 4), Pangngala’.
Ending of a simbong (SA 21-25), Awan.
Ending of a simbong, Se'seng.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Influence of the vowel pronounced on the interval of a second
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The widening of the harmonic interval is linked in particular to the vowel change. When the vowels pass from [o] to [e], the soloist (who sings a closed [e] –the French é- verging on open [ɛ] –the French è) rises in pitch while the drone stays stable or drops. The sharp formants of the soloist’s [è] help to pull his voice upwards. Thus the widening of the ratio is linked –among other factors –to the vowel used. Certain singers say they ‘hang high’for the [e] (dibasse ma'do) and ‘hang low’for the [o] (dibasse ma' diong).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Example of vowel change.
Example of vowel change at the beginning of a simbong, Awan (21-25).

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Global instability of the harmonic interval between pieces.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: One chorus does not necessarily try to use the same second in each of its pieces. The interval is very rarely stable either within the same piece or between two different pieces. A chorus can finish on a medium second (ratio 9/8 - 204 cents at Poka 2), then in the following piece on a very wide second (ratio 7/6 - 252 cents, Poka 4); or inversely, it can finish on a wide second (ratio 8/7 - 244 cents) and, in one of the following pieces, on a very small second (ratio 11/10 - 165 cents).

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Ornamenting the unison is a practice common to many repertoires, and especially in the badong and simbong.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Good singers know how to ornament the unison. The various vernacular phrases are evidence of the importance giving to changing the voice. They say ‘change the voices so as to embellish them’.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: The unison is ornamented by a soloist in the badong.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Toraja terms describing vocal ornamentation.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Parallelism, drone and heterophony are various types of Toraja plurivocality.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The vocal or instrumental parts may have any of the following relations to each other: unison, heterophony, parallelism (in thirds, fourths, or fifths), one line moving while another (i.e., a drone) stays steady.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Dondi’ in parallel fifths, 1991.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: All the repertoires are intended to be performed in unison except for the simbong, io-io and the music for the pakorong ritual.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Dondi’ at Sangngalla', 1991.
Badong chorus of about fifty singers, recorded at Gandang Batu in 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: At an interval of a second.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: In most of the repertoires the soloist sings (or plays) in intervals of a second (untempered), an interval prevailing not only in the drone repertoires –simbong, io-io and the music of suling deata and suling bonde flutes –but also in the funeral repertoires which have no drone –such as badong and dondi’.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Simbong recorded near Pangala, in 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The men’s unison in the badong can be backed in thirds by women or, occasionally, also by men. In the dondi’ the same melody can be performed in thirds.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Badong in thirds. Recorded at Karongian, Baruppu', 30 June 1993. Badong sullena bating. Last day of funeral.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Dondi’ and badong can be sung in fifths. From the examples collected, the badong is more generally sung in thirds or fourths, and the sitting chorus dondi’ in fifths.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Certain repertoires use vowel-changing techniques.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: These techniques, found in the great repertoires of badong and simbong, consist of play on changing vowels, corresponding to a variation in spectrum, caused by inverting the points of articulation.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Strictly speaking, basse means something hung on two sides. It implies the idea of bilaterality, by referring to something happening in two parts, what hangs on two opposite but not necessarily symmetrical sides. Relating to a mountain pass the term evokes the start of the descent after the ascent (Veen and Tammu 1972). Basse also designates finishing something. In music, it designates a change of vowel or frequency, from a very low to a very high note for example (as when a flautist plays an octave leap by overblowing).

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Description of the meaning of basse: in a drawing, an informer opposes a ‘suspended house’(banua ditoke') hanging straight down from the sky (Toraja myth) to a ‘string dropping down on both sides’(ulang dibasse). Basse implies two sides.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Analyzing the spectrograms reveals the acoustic specificities of the vowel play. On the [o] the spectrum extends from h1 to h4, while on the [e] the spectrum widens, giving rise to three formant zones: h1 to h3, h7 to h9, and h12-h13-h14. The front closed vowels have a much wider field of frequencies, as their formants are further apart. When changing from [o] to [e] there is a modification in an aspect of the timbre: the brilliance, determined by the formants’frequencies. The first two formants of the [o] are close together whilst those of [e] are wide apart.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Spectrogram 12. Two beginnings of simbong compared. Each effects a basse vowel change, passing from [o] to [e] to [o]. The sound chosen here corresponds to the spectrogram below, from the region of Pangngala'.

Spectrogram 12. Comparison of two beginnings of simbong performed by a chorus of about twenty men (above, Se'seng region –below, Pangngala’region). The sound chosen corresponds to the spectrogram above.
Spectrogram 13. From the ending of a simbong (men’s chorus recorded at Poka). The words kurre-kurre sumanga’ are transformed into koré-korésomengngé as all the vowels shift towards [o] and [e].

Frequencies of the first two formants of the vowels of the French language, taken from a table by Suzanne Fürniss in ‘La technique du jodel chez les Pygmées Aka’(Centrafrique). Une étude phonétique et acoustique’, Cahiers de musiques traditionnelles, vol. 4:172.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The vowels [o] and [e]are favored. Both are half-closed. When changing from [o] to [e], the movement is from a back to front articulation point, but the extent of opening stays the same. The opposition is not between closed and open vowels, but between front and back position. Here it is not the aperture that modifies the timbre, but a change in the vowel’s articulation point. Depending on the latter the various zones of the spectrum are unequally covered. If the vowels are uniformized into [o] and [e], this is because the singers prefer alternating between narrow and wide spectra.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Phonetic triangle, after Luc Bouquiaux, France Cloarec-Heiss, Jacqueline Thomas, Initiation àla phonétique, Paris, PUF, 1976.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The choral quality of Toraja voices is distinguished by its homogeneity.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Vocal homogeneity is noticeable in the unified timbres, in the brassy vocal texture, and in the search through vowel change for alternating harmonic spectra.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Badong at Penduan Ra'ba', 2001. Recording: Badong of Baruppu' in fourths.
Badong of Limbong Pangngala’, 1993.
Simbong of a group from Pangngala’, recorded at Poka, 1993.
Dondi’ in thirds.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Numerous ensembles are organized in two named groups.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Most of the ensembles –badong, simbong, nani, io-io, suling bonde, suling deata, geso'-geso', bugi', and gandang have one feature of their structure in common: an organization in two groups (vocal or instrumental) –between a chorus or other group forming a base and a soloist who embroiders a second above or below.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Organization of a suling bonde group, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: A group of four drummers is arranged in three roles: the leader (pangindo’), two persons beating in response constituting the musical base (pangrepe), and an embroiderer (pa’pasala). The base players begin, followed by the embroiderer, then the leader. Two adopt a melodic role and two a base role –yet another example of two-group organization.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: VIDEO: Drumming at Sa'dan, 2001.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The soloist is assisted by one or more assistants.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The soloist or leader (indo’ ‘mother’) is aided by two types of assistant: ‘supports, props’(passa'pi') and ‘sustainer’(pa’tokon).
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Table of names for the various roles in several repertoires.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: The grouping is hierarchised
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The principle of subordination is obvious: the ‘lieutenants’depend on their leader; the group is subordinate to the soloist. This subordination accentuates the superiority of the soloist –the only one with the ornamental expertise. A structure of 4+1 or 3+1 or 2+1 is recurrent.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: In a hierarchical grouping the musicians are interdependent.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The interdependence –between a leader and the group, between a leader and his assistants, between the four soloist groups and the chorus –is evident in the sharing of musical tasks. This principle hinders individual expression, even for the soloist; the singers never express themselves alone but always as members of a whole. The form’s immutability consecrates the unity of the community.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: Certain formations do not subordinate voices to one another.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: In certain cases –dondi’, serang mundan, gelong maro, gelong bugi', badong to buda –the same part is sung by all.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Badong in unison before setting off for the grave, Bokko, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: When the music is to mark the movements of the corpse, a single badong song is sung as a unitary chorus –by all the performers, in unison and without alternating soloists –because all the living want to take part in the gesture of farewell. The dance is then ‘open’to all. Considered as ‘bastard and amateur’, it is called badong sirauta'nak, ‘badong in which several grains mix’or badong sangrupa ‘of only one form’or again badong sikalombu ‘muddy badong’. All those who wish –who like and know how to sing –join the circle.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Badong in unison, chorus of Rantetayo, recorded at Tapparan, funeral of Ne' Sakkung, 1993.
Badong chorus recorded at Tumbang Datu, Bokko region.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: In the major celebrations, the groups of singers sing side-by-side and separately.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Although these kinds of music are not subject to any rhythmic coordination, they are performed simultaneously: they are juxtaposed. This juxtaposition is fixed, durable and deliberate.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: VIDEO: Juxtaposition of a male and female chorus. Images: Yves Defrance, Lo'ko’Lemo, 2005.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: IN THE RITUALS OF THE WEST

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: At certain funerals, or even before the celebration begins, while the deceased is lying in the house, people watch over the dead man and sing the dondi’ lamentation. At Baruppu' several groups sing in the house of the deceased.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: In the house where the deceased rests, two groups sing in two different rooms, about ten meters apart. The polymusic is only noticeable during the pauses of the choruses closest to the microphone. Recorded at Kendenan, Baruppu', 14 August 1993. Chorus leader: Bo'ti'.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: Pieces of music juxtaposed for welcoming the guests.
ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Various forms of music greet the guests’progress through the area of celebration. These musics come one after the other, piled on top of one another through overlapping only a few meters apart. The intensity of the mortar covers the long sighs of the elegiac complaint marakka, sad and insistent, musically close to weeping; the women’s short melodies, plain and static, of the chorus katia mingle with the powerful accents of the male badong, ceaselessly scrambled by the master of ceremonies’badly adjusted megaphone. Mixture of registers, of timbres, and of rhythms.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Superposition of sounds of the rice mortar, squealing pigs, and megaphone during a funeral at Tallung Lipu, 1993. From the moment a group of guests arrives at the gate, the rice mortar, fifty meters away, is pounded by eight women. Gift of the guests to the family, the tethered pigs, squealing non-stop, are first of all brought in and placed in the ceremonial field, their cries joining the sound of the mortar in a deafening din.

Superposition of uncoordinated musical sources: marakka singer and flautist, badong chorus, gong, and then ma'katia female chorus. Once the guests approach the reception tent they are inundated with sounds of all kinds. Tallung Lipu, funeral, 1993.

ANTECEDENT.TITRE: IN THE RITUALS OF THE EAST

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The maro ritual can be performed by several families. Each family has its team of music-making celebrants: drums, officiants, singers. On the last day, all these teams come together on the ceremonial field. Thus, at Torea, in November 1993, I saw five masts, five drums, five groups of officiants and five groups of girls, as well as several groups of informal singers all brought together in a single place. Here, musics of different natures are juxtaposed: trance songs, officiants’chanting, and drums for dances.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Juxtaposition of a trance song (gelong unnondo ‘song for leaping’), drums, and shouting. The song is for summoning the divinities to come to the ceremonial site.
Juxtaposition of the officiants’chanted songs with the drums. Four old officiants sing a hymn to the ceremonial mast, while drumbeats accompany the girls’dance gellu' in the background, Torea, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: This polymusic is a sign of social prestige for the family organizing the celebration.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The greater the number of choruses, the greater the scale of the celebration –the more the family displays its power and status to one and all. Thus the primary purpose of Toraja rituals –to guarantee the comfort of the deceased’s soul –is often subverted by a political aim of social promotion –acquiring prestige and status through lavishing rice, meat and sounds on the other families and neighboring villages.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Family of the dead woman Ne' Sakkung, Tapparan, 1993 (Notice the dog-collar).

PROPOSITION.TITRE: This polymusic demonstrates the exchange between the families.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: Two groups of donors are distinguished: consanguines (cousins or descendants of cousins) and affines (relations by marriage). When the former bring pigs or presents they are not considered debts that must be repaid. Presents from relations by marriage, however –pigs, palm wine, rice, or dancers –will be counted as debts. They will be returned in exchange at other celebrations. Thus a chorus can be a form of debt.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Bringing pigs, funeral of Puang Laso Gau' Lembang, Mengkendek, 1991.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: From the singers’point of view this polymusic embodies a territorial principle.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The groups’superimposition results from their refusal to mix. Gathered in the same place, the choruses, each from different regions or villages, sing simultaneously but separately and competitively. Their differences are most obviously expressed by the color of their dress, given to them by the sponsoring family for their performance. The polymusic is the result of different regional units all expressing themselves at the same time.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: In the center of the dance circle are spell-averters (pa'sande boko, ‘the rearguard’), Tapparan, 1993.

PROPOSITION.TITRE: From a religious point of view, these polymusics may be considered as sound offerings.
PROPOSITION.COMMENTAIRE: The abundance of animal offerings matches the musical offerings. These are displayed simultaneously though separately on the ceremonial field. Their juxtaposition signifies the humans’appeal to immaterial entities –ancestors and divinities. The juxtaposed musics, just like the food offerings, put the living in contact with the invisible.
PROPOSITION.LEGENDE: Hecatomb at a funeral celebration, Tikala, 1991.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: Buffaloes and pigs are killed by the dozens. Scarcely has a buffalo collapsed with a perceptible death-rattle when the next one has its throat cut. Finally, they are butchered in public and the pieces put on show on leaves on the ground before being shared out, following precise rules linked to the inheritance of land for rice growing. Like the songs performed in polymusic, slaughtering buffaloes is subject to witchcraft. Some cast spells so that the buffalo does not die immediately: a slow death is held to be a malediction.

Donnee_Media.LEGENDE: Butchering the buffalo.
Sharing and redistribution.

ANTECEDENT.COMMENTAIRE: The same process of cutting up is at work. In the badong songs the words are cut up between four groups of singers, just as the buffaloes are divided into four (tepo tedong), cut up meticulously and then distributed to different groups. The redistribution, effected hierarchically, in both cases passes through the mediation of the social group.
